div1.p: Robert Carter writes to Weymouth Edward Tucker, July 9, 1731, to remind him of earlier correspondence and to alert him to a bill of exchange.

div1.head: Letter from Robert Carter to Edward Tucker, July 9, 1731

opener.dateline:
Rappa[hannock, Lancaster County, Virginia]
July 9. 1731
Edward Tucker Esqr

div1.p:
I have some time since advisd you of a Noat I had
drawn upon yo payable to Alderman Perry for two hundred
pounds and yo. have also already been acquainted with my consig[[n]]:
ment of 20 hogsheads stemm'd tobo to yo in yr Ship the Portland

The trouble of this is to Advise you that I have
this day drawn upon you a bill of Exchange for one hundred
pounds payable to Colo George Braxton that I desire you to answer
at time & place to my Accot who am
div1.closer:
Sir
Your most humble Servt
Copy Per Dove

div1.head: NOTES
div1.note: Source copy consulted: Letter book, 1731 July 9-1732 July 13 , Robert Carter Papers (acc. no. 3807), Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia.

Robert Carter generally used a return address of "Rappahannock" for the river on which he lived rather than "Corotoman," the name of his home, on his correspondence, especially to merchants abroad. The county and colony have been added for clarity.

[1] John Russell commanded the Portland, a vessel owned by Weymouth merchant Edward Tucker. (Survey Report 9729 detailing the Weymouth Port Books, Virginia Colonial Records Project, Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia.)

[2] The Bailey was a London ship owned by William Dawkins and commanded at various times by Adam Graves (1725-1730) and by Thomas Dove (1731-1732). She was a vessel of some 250 tons and carried 15-17 crew members. (Survey report 6801 summarizing Adm. 68/195, 156v, and other data in Adm. 68/194 and /196, found in the microfilms of the Virginia Colonial Records Project, Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia; A letter of Carter's executors to Dawkins 1738 May 10 refers to "your ship Bailey.")
